Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: They occasionally give casual advice when asked about minor career choices.
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat with my family lighting up with reminders about tonight’s dinner. Mom’s message was clear: “Don’t be late, everyone’s counting on you to be there.” I knew how much these gatherings meant, especially since we hadn’t all been together in weeks. At the same time, my mentee, Jamie, texted me, “Can we talk tonight? I have to decide about this internship by tomorrow.” Jamie rarely asked for help, and I knew how much this decision was weighing on them. I felt the pressure mounting—my family expected me to show up, laugh, and be present, while Jamie needed my guidance, even if just for a short call. I wanted to be the reliable sibling, the one who never missed a dinner, but I also wanted to be the mentor who never let someone down. My chest tightened as I tried to figure out how to be in two places at once, torn between the warmth of my family and the responsibility I felt toward Jamie.
